awd_titl_txt: PFI-RP:  Clinical Decision Support Tool to Identify Patients Diagnosed with Heart Failure Who are at High Risk of 30-day Hospital Readmission
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation – Research Partnerships (PFI-RP) project is to reduce the burden of heart failure across the healthcare system. Heart failure is the most common cause for hospital admission and readmission in the US (> one million patients annually). Many heart failure readmissions are thought to be preventable. To reduce readmissions, healthcare organizations are penalized for high rates of 30-day hospital readmission. Excess readmission penalties were ~$560 million across all hospitals in the US in 2020, with ~2,500 hospitals incurring penalties. Customer discovery interviews, conducted with numerous stakeholders of healthcare organizations, suggested a strong interest in a Clinical Decision Support tool to identify patients diagnosed with heart failure and who are at high risk of 30-day hospital readmission. By accurately stratifying risk for 30-day hospital readmission, this software tool empowers clinicians involved in discharge planning to make more informed decisions about the timing of hospital discharge and the efficient use of post-discharge follow-up services, including allocation of remote monitoring hardware. This solution can improve patient outcomes while reducing costs associated with avoidable hospitalizations and the corresponding penalties for hospitals.

The proposed project focuses on the development and commercialization of a novel, machine learning-based clinical decision support software tool to predict 30-day readmissions for hospitalized patients diagnosed with heart failure. The proposed technology includes higher frequency physiologic data in the predictive algorithm and the software tool will be capable of processing this data in combination with clinical variables with low latency (<3 seconds) to quantify each patient’s risk of 30-day hospital readmission at the point of care. This technology has the potential to assist with the identification and management of high-risk patients diagnosed with heart failure and improve the quality of care for this vulnerable patient population.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits: This project supports and accelerates the commercialization of a Clinical Decision Support tool that accurately classifies risk for 30-day readmission for hospitalized patients with a diagnosis of Congestive Heart Failure (CHF), enabling higher quality discharge planning, post-discharge care, and more effective allocation of post-discharge resources including but not limited to remote patient monitoring. We developed and externally validated a prototype machine learning-based model using large-scale proprietary clinical datasets from Johns Hopkins, and also from Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center. This algorithm uses physiologic time series (PTS) and clinical data routinely captured in the electronic health record to predict risk of 30-day hospital readmission for patients with CHF and achieving 43% improvement over the standard of care, quantified in a small-scale pilot study.  

The first aim for this PFI-RP proposal was to strengthen the existing CHF readmission risk prediction model to operate at clinically desirable levels of accuracy. This was accomplished using a more complex set of parameters and proprietary feature extraction and selection techniques.

Our second aim was to externally validate the model using an independent large-scale clinical dataset that was not used for any aspect of the original model development or training. This allowed us to further assess the robustness of the model.

Our third aim was to conduct a pilot study at Johns Hopkins to assess usability, clinical utility and financial value proposition in a real-world scenario. This study enabled us to optimize the final configuration of the model and address any technical challenges associated with data processing and implementation related factors such as user interface and experience, and quantify the cost savings potential by reducing 30-day hospital readmissions.

This project contributes to applied clinical data science research and development by identifying novel features derived from clinical and physiological data in the inpatient setting that have relevance to an important clinical outcome (30-day hospital readmission). These novel features that were derived have potential for broader physiologic relevance, because the ability to stratify risk for readmission is a surrogate for risk or future illness (or incompletely resolved illness). The project could also present how machine learning can be used to integrate multiple clinical data streams embedded within a real world electronic health record, including routine clinical variables, laboratory results, and physiologic features, to develop a clinically meaningful Clinical Decision Support tool.

Broader impacts in terms of societal, economic and commercial benefit: Congestive Heart Failure (CHF) is the most common cause for hospital admission and readmission in the US, accounting for >1 million admissions annually. Hospital readmissions are independently associated with negative patient outcomes, and an estimated 70% of those readmissions are considered preventable; To reduce readmissions, the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Service (CMS) penalizes healthcare organizations for high rates of 30-day hospital readmission. Re-admission penalties were over ~$300 million across all hospitals in recent years, with thousands of hospitals being affected. CMS imposes these kinds of penalties for high rates of readmission related to numerous common diagnoses. Although our software tool is focused on CHF, we envision that the type of CDS tool we are planning to commercialize could be extended to apply to other diagnoses in hospitalized patients as well. In addition, our project provided a unique opportunity for graduate students and the post-doctoral fellow to interact closely with an industry partner who is a leader in this area, preparing the next generation of entrepreneurs in this high-tech industry. This training was tailored to the business and commercialization aspects of deploying predictive analytics tools in hospital settings.


Last Modified: 07/23/2024
Modified by: Nauder Faraday
